awd_titl_txt: Dissertation Research in Economics: Trade and Demography in British India
awd_abstract_narration:
An enduring debate in South Asian economic history concerns the consequences of two centuries of British rule on economic performance and social welfare. Measurement has been a contentious issue: wages, prices, and agricultural yields have been used and criticized by scholars. However, population indicators which are known to have a major influence on economic activity have not featured prominently in this debate. In other preindustrial societies, we know that birth and death rates varied systematically with economic shocks, so we expect to learn more about how an economy like the British Indian economy developed through these demographic parameters. In particular, this proposal revisits the question of the impact major infrastructure provision, i.e., of the rollout of railroads on the welfare of ordinary people as an illustration of this method.

The project will collect and analyze demographic data from British Indian censuses, vital statistics, and economic data from colonial statistical serials from the 1870s through the 1920s. The first contribution of the project will consist of the construction of a new general-use demographic dataset of annual births and deaths at the district level, providing a new and more disaggregated description of the demographic history of South Asia than currently exists. The second contribution is a more thorough understanding of the dynamic interplay between demography and economic factors in this period, such as the causes of the mortality decline and the efficacy of public health expenditures. Finally, this research will employ these data to examine whether or how opening up to trade and the arrival of the railroads affected population growth. Given that theories of trade and Malthusian demography in conjunction imply that gains from trade should be reflected in higher fertility and/or lower mortality, this research will explore theoretically and test empirically a mechanism that could explain how opening up to trade may fail to improve per-capita welfare.

por.por_cntn:
Economists since the days of Malthus have understood that economic development and population growth are closely linked in pre-industrial societies: structural features of the economy and transitory economic shocks are reflected in population density, fertility and mortality (which in turn affect the economy). The empirical foundation for much of our understanding of this relationship comes from Western Europe, rather than the developing world. Studying colonial India represents an opportunity to refine our understanding of how demography and development are related: furthermore, this Malthusian viewpoint suggests that demographic data can support a deeper understanding of the colonial Indian economy.

This grant supported the collection of vital statistics from archives of British Indian public health and Census reports over the late nineteenth and early twentieth centuries. Using tools from the fields of empirical demography and high-performance numerical optimization, systematic errors leading to undercounts of births and deaths in the public-health reports were corrected by using the population age-structure recorded in decennial Censuses. This new dataset of vital rates provides the first clear picture of annual birth and death rates at a disaggregated level for colonial South Asia. Once the dissertation is submitted, this new dataset will be made available to the public, and will be of interest to scholars in diverse fields, including economic history, development, demography, and public health.

This project used economic and econometric analysis to investigate a number of questions around colonial Indian economic demography. A first sub-project documents a revised understanding of the trajectory of Indian demographic trends at the sub-regional level, and ongoing research revisits the timing and causes of the mortality decline of the early twentieth century. A second sub-project focuses on an empirical test of the responsiveness of vital rates to rainfall shocks, and demonstrates that colonial Indian demographic differences from pre-industrial Europe appear to be more of degree than of kind. Finally, a third sub-project studies the impact of the British-built railroad network on population growth. A theoretical model of international trade augmented with a Malthusian mechanism suggests that the gains from trade associated with integration into national and international markets would show up in the short-run in higher fertility and lower mortality and in the long-run simply in higher population density: these hypotheses are supported by the data.

Our understanding of Europe's preindustrial economic development has long been informed fundamentally by careful empirical work on its population history. This project takes the first step in an analogous approach to the study of India's historical development, and opens up new avenues of research on the consequences of colonial institutions and investments on Indian economic growth. It therefore broadens our perspectives on the nature of economic development and stagnation over the long run, a matter of salience when policymakers think about the developing world today. Furthermore, where the developing world continues to feature Malthusian effects, the story of the British railroads suggests that policymakers may want to consider demography when thinking about the long-term consequences of reforms and investments.
